document.heading: Energy Innovation and Savings Amendment Act of 2012

history.narrative: Law 19-252, the “Energy Innovation and Savings Amendment Act of 2012,” was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 19-749. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on Nov. 1, 2012 and Nov. 15, 2012, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on Dec. 7, 2012, it was assigned Act No. 19-562 and transmitted to Congress for its review. D.C. Law 19-252 became effective on Mar. 19, 2013.

section.heading: Definitions.
section.text: For the purposes of this chapter, the term:

para.text: “Air conditioner” means an appliance, system, or mechanism designed to remove heat and humidity from ambient air for thermal comfort.

“Chain of stores” means 2 or more stores located within the District that are engaged in the same general field of business under the same business name or that operate under common ownership or management or pursuant to a franchise agreement with the same franchisor.

“Commercial property” means income-producing property as identified under zoning classifications that would allow for uses such as office buildings, retail stores, and service facilities pursuant to Chapter 7 of Title 11 of the District of Columbia Municipal Regulations (11 DCMR § 700 et seq.); provided, that the term “commercial property” shall not include a small store, hotel, or restaurant.
The owner or lessee of the portion of a commercial building or structure that is a retail or wholesale establishment that sells goods or provides services to consumers; and
The record owner or lessee of any other portion of a commercial building or structure.

“Small store” means a retail or wholesale establishment that sells goods or provides services to consumers and occupies less than 4,000 square feet of retail or wholesale space, excluding storage space, and is not one of a chain of stores.

annoGroup.heading: Editor's Notes
annoGroup.annotation: Section 301 of D.C. Law 19-252 provided that the Mayor shall issue rules to implement the provisions of the act within 180 days of its effective date [March 19, 2013].

section.heading: Commercial property energy conservation.
section.text: A commercial property shall keep exterior doors and windows closed when an air conditioner that cools the adjacent area is in operation, except:

para.text: During a reasonable period of ingress and egress of people or the delivery or shipping of goods;
Where the door is intended for vehicular access to or for a loading dock;
When an emergency situation exists requiring an exterior door or window to be kept open; or
When a commercial property implements an alternative strategy authorized by the Mayor through regulation as a reasonably equivalent means of conserving energy.
If the Mayor determines that a violation of this chapter has occurred, the person in violation shall be subject to the penalties set forth in this section.

The Mayor shall impose a penalty on retail establishments in violation of this chapter, which shall be a class 4 infraction under the schedule of fines in Chapter 32 of Title 16 of the District of Columbia Municipal Regulations (16 DCMR § 3200 et seq.)
Retail establishments shall not be fined more than once in a 24-hour period for a violation of § 8-1772.02.
If payment of any amounts due under this section is not received by or before the due date, a penalty shall be added as provided by the Mayor through rulemaking.

A violation of this chapter shall be a civil infraction for purposes of Chapter 18 of Title 2 [§ 2-1801.01 et seq.] (“Civil Infractions Act”). Civil fines, penalties, and fees may be imposed as sanctions for an infraction of the provisions of this chapter, or the rules issued under authority of this chapter, pursuant to the Civil Infractions Act. Adjudication of infractions shall be pursuant to the Civil Infractions Act.
The enforcement of this chapter shall be administered by the Director of the District Department of the Environment.
